questions.question_text: Pentest results indicate that voice over IP traffic is traversing a network. Which of the following tools will decode a packet capture and extract the voice conversations?

discussion.content:
D is correct (for /L %V in (1 1 254) do PING -n 1 192.168.2.%V | FIND /I "Reply").
Tested, it works in CMD.

questions.question_text: Which command lets a tester enumerate alive systems in a class C network via ICMP using native Windows tools?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
-sP ping Question is not about port scanning and port status but about IP adress and alive host. for this reason the best is -sP
-sP ping scan provides status of host

Selected Answer: C
-sS Stealth scan (a hacker use this)

comments.content:
This is correct. 
-sn (No port scan)
This option tells Nmap not to do a port scan after host discovery, and only print out the available hosts that responded to the host discovery probes. This is often known as a “ping scan”

It does. "In previous releases of Nmap, -sn was known as -sP."

https://linux.die.net/man/1/nmap

discussion.content: -sP does not show up in NMAP manual
SS is used to scan ports in the lower 1000 by default. Not ip addresses

questions.question_text: A hacker is attempting to see which IP addresses are currently active on a network. Which NMAP switch would the hacker use?

discussion.content: Is A, think that when you perform a log in, OS is only comparing the hash value of your password with the /etc/shadow in Linux and SAM file in windows.

isnt option d right too?
correct me if wrong

questions.question_text: How does an operating system protect the passwords used for account logins?

choices.A: The operating system performs a one-way hash of the passwords.
choices.B: The operating system stores the passwords in a secret file that users cannot find.
choices.C: The operating system encrypts the passwords, and decrypts them when needed.
choices.D: The operating system stores all passwords in a protected segment of non-volatile memory.

questions.question_text: Which technical characteristic do Ethereal/Wireshark, TCPDump, and Snort have in common?

discussion.content: pcap is an application programming interface (API) for capturing network traffic. While the name is an abbreviation of packet capture, that is not the API's proper name. Unix-like systems implement pcap in the libpcap library; libpcap, WinPcap, and Npcap provide the packet-capture and filtering engines of many open-source and commercial network tools, including protocol analyzers (packet sniffers), network monitors, network intrusion detection systems, traffic-generators and network-testers.

choices.B: They send alerts to security monitors.
choices.D: They use the same packet capture utility.
choices.C: They use the same packet analysis engine.
